head.title: U.S. Open Draw Yields An Interesting Mix

Yesterday's draw for the United States Open generated more speculation about the future than about the first round. Top-seeded Andre Agassi, the defending champion, and No. 4 Pete Sampras might meet in the semifinals; Serena Williams, the women's defending champion, and her sister Venus, the hottest player in the sport, are in opposite halves of the draw and could only meet in the final.

But things could get interesting long before then. Pat Rafter, the two-time Open champion and the most dangerous unseeded player, might meet 15th-seeded Mark Philippoussis in the third round. Philippoussis could face Jan-Michael Gambill in the second round.
No. 11 Tim Henman could face the second-most feared floater, Richard Krajicek, in the third round. Agassi could face one of two talented players, Hicham Arazi or Wayne Ferreira, in the third round.

A few-round matches are noteworthy. No. 7 Conchita Martinez will face Amy Frazier, a semifinalist at the Acura Classic near San Diego. Mary Pierce, the French Open champion now struggling with a shoulder injury, goes against Alexandra Stevenson, who reached the Wimbledon semifinals last year. Two rounds later, the winner of that match could face the the serve-and-volleyer Lisa Raymond, who should be motivated after being left off the United States Olympics team.

No. 1 Martina Hingis and No. 3 Venus Williams anchor the top half of the women's draw. With Amelie Mauresmo out with an injury, 18th-ranked Chanda Rubin just missed being seeded and is a potential third-round opponent for Monica Seles, seeded sixth. Seles's projected fourth-round opponent is No. 15 Jennifer Capriati, the player she outlasted in an epic Open semifinal in 1991.
In the bottom half, No. 2 Lindsay Davenport is seeded to meet No. 5 Serena Williams in the quarterfinals and Pierce in the semifinals.
